awd_titl_txt: EAGER: The Role of Lipids in Modulating the Synaptic Plasticity of Ion Channels
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will elucidate the microscopic mechanisms involved in the transport of ions and other signals across membrane-associated protein channels. The investigators will focus on the dynamic and structural features of the biological membranes which are involved in these processes. Eventually, these studies may bring new insights into the understanding of learning and memory. Importantly, the study will implement non-invasive scattering techniques to study the membranes, leveraging the powerful resources at national facilities such as the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) and Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL). The investigators will engage undergraduates and high school students who do not historically have access to research experience. This project will create opportunities for these students to perform cutting-edge research at leading research facilities in the country (e.g., ORNL and BNL), thereby inspiring a new generation of scientists. This project will combine experiments with data analysis and computer simulations. Students will advance their programming and laboratory skills. These skills are imperative for both science and industry. Students will participate in a paid summer internship and/or thesis projects. Moreover, these skills will give students an advantage applying for positions in academia, research organizations, and industry. 

Biological membranes are highly complex structures consisting of a lipid bilayer and associated molecules. In this project the investigators aim to study the molecular origins of the force from lipids (FFL) principle and its role in the activity of ion channels. They will harness non-invasive scattering techniques, in conjunction with droplet interface bilayers (DIBs) measurements, to study these molecular mechanisms.  These conceptually distant techniques will allow the investigators to get a comprehensive picture of processes involved in ion channel activity at the molecular scale (via scattering) and its relation to stimulated learning, memory, and synaptic plasticity (via DIBs).  Synaptic plasticity describes biological processes that enable learning and memory due to the physicochemical and electromechanical activities between synapses. By controlling the activity of the pore-forming ion channels embedded in membranes, one can manipulate the membrane resting potential, and other signals, simply by controlling the flow of ions across the cell membrane.  Understanding the detailed, multi-scale molecular mechanisms underlying synaptic plasticity are of fundamental importance in gaining insights into the molecular basis of learning and memory. This high-risk, potentially transformative project aims to make a hitherto unknown connection between the cascade-like relaxation dynamics in the biological membrane (influenced by the FFL) and synaptic plasticity on a larger scale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to study the molecular mechanisms underlying learning and memory by studying the dynamics of biological membranes and their role in synaptic plasticity. By integrating experimental techniques, electrophysiological measurements, high-throughput computer simulations, and data analysis, our research provided new insights into the behavior of lipid membranes under electrical stimulation and their role in neuronal processes.

Key Outcomes and Findings:

  1. Advancement in Understanding Synaptic Plasticity:

Our research has significantly enhanced the understanding of synaptic plasticity in phospholipid membranes. We discovered a new form of long-term potentiation (LTP) in lipid membranes, demonstrating a mechanism for memory storage. This finding provides a new perspective on how memory may be encoded at the molecular level.

  1. Innovative Methodologies and Tools:

We developed and utilized cutting-edge experimental techniques such as Droplet Interface Bilayers (DIBs) and Inelastic X-ray Scattering (IXS) to study the dielectric properties and energy landscapes of lipid membranes. These techniques have broadened the scope of biophysical research and can be applied to various fields, including pharmaceutical development and materials science. Specifically, our findings have implications for the development of advanced drug delivery systems and biomimetic materials. By understanding how lipid membranes interact with external stimuli, we can design more efficient and targeted therapies for various medical conditions.

  1. Computational Modeling and Simulations:

Leveraging high-performance computing facilities like Summit and Frontier at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, we conducted detailed simulations to predict memory effects in lipid membranes. We developed a new coarse-grained model of a membrane under electrical stimulation. We also developed a theoretical model for understanding the electrical response of a membrane as a nonlinear circuit element. These models help bridge the gap between microscopic and macroscopic perspectives, providing a comprehensive view of energy storage and dissipation mechanisms.

  1. Educational and Training Contributions:

The project provided training opportunities for students and researchers, equipping them with advanced skills in experimental techniques, data analysis, and computational modeling. These educational efforts have prepared a new generation of scientists for careers in academia, industry, and emerging interdisciplinary fields.

Broader Impacts:

  1. Public Health and Well-Being:

Our research contributes to the broader understanding of neurological disorders and cognitive health. The insights gained can inform the development of new therapies for conditions such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases, ultimately benefiting patients and their families.

  1. Economic and Workforce Development, and Environmental Sustainability:
    • By developing new technologies and medical devices based on our findings, the project has the potential to create jobs and stimulate economic growth. The commercialization of these innovations can lead to advancements in biotechnology and healthcare industries. Our research inspires novel approaches for the creation of efficient energy storage systems and biomimetic materials, with the potential for increasing sustainability in various industries. These technologies can reduce environmental impact and contribute to global efforts in addressing climate change and resource conservation.
  2. Educational Outreach and Public Engagement:

The dissemination of our findings through public lectures, workshops, publications, and new educational materials has increased public awareness and understanding of biophysical research. Outreach efforts in the community for underrepresented groups were also undertaken to promote the pursuit of science. By making complex scientific concepts accessible, we inspire future generations to pursue careers in STEM fields.

In summary, this project has made significant contributions to the scientific understanding of synaptic plasticity in biological membranes at the molecular level. The methodologies and findings have broad implications for medical, pharmaceutical, and environmental applications. By advancing scientific knowledge and providing educational opportunities, the project supports the NSF’s mission to promote the progress of science and benefit society.
